Things were going very slowly.  The original seed topology (no hidden nodes) 
was still alive and kicking, and battling it out for first place in the 
population, which means that things weren't exactly progressing...

So I decided to speed things up.  I chopped down the number of networks in 
the population so that packets get returned sooner.  Found a bug in my 
offspring allocation code in the process...oops...but that's fixed now.

So now I'm trying to get through the generations faster in an attempt to 
make some progress.  Problem is, I think I may have done myself a 
disservice.  By having the evaluation code start at the reduction side and 
work its way up to enlargement, it seems the pressure is to create a network 
that merely averages its pixel inputs.  And I'm not convinced that it will 
be able to (easily) break away from that pressure, even as topology is 
added.  It might, but I'm thinking that I would be better off if I just went 
ahead and calculated all activations rather than trying to short-circuit the 
calculations for less fit networks.  What do you guys think?

-- John
